Name: Is there a distinct category of dual for verbal agreement with a dual subject?
Is non-agreement in number between the nominal subject and verbal predicate possible?
Can finite verbs agree in number with the nominal object?
Can an adnominal property word agree with the noun in case?
Comment: The only adjective that agrees with the noun in case (and number) is buorre 'good', but it does not fully agree in all cases. E.g., buorre ovdamearka (good.NOM example.NOM), buori ovdamearkka (good.GENACC example.GENACC), buriin ovdamearkkain (good.COM example.COM), but buori ovdamearkkas (good.GENACC example.LOC). Additionally, many if not most present-day speakers (and even language authorities) use the non-declined buorre (NOM) in all cases.

Name: Are there cases that do not show agreement in terms of case?
Comment: There are cases that do not show full agreement, but have genitive modifiers instead.

Name: Can adpositions be used to mark core verbal arguments?
Can adpositions be used to mark non-core/oblique verbal arguments?
Can non-finite clauses entail a special way for a core argument (S/A) marking?
Can non-finite clauses entail a special way for a core argument (P) marking?
Do characteristics of object referent (topicality, animacy, definiteness) influence object marking?
Does object marking correlate with aspectuality?
Does the marking of the object depend on the verb conjugation form?
Is there differential subject marking?
Can S and A be conflated morphologically across clause boundaries, i.e. act as syntactic pivot?
Can S and P be conflated morphologically across clause boundaries, i.e. act as syntactic pivot?
Is there a grammatical device for habituality?
Is there a grammatical device for frequentative?
Comment: There are many derivational suffixes with frequentative meaning.

Name: Is there a grammatical device for progressivity?
Is it common to use a verb in the present tense for future time reference?
Is there a grammatical device for immediate future?
Comment: The adverb aiddo 'just' makes the prxoimative function of the progressive (”action essive”) form even more explicit.

Name: Is there a grammatical device for pluperfect?
Can aspect be expressed overtly on the negative marker?
Can tense be expressed overtly on the negative marker?
Is there grammatical marking of mirativity?
Is there morphological marking on the verb dedicated to the expression of desire or wish?
Is there morphological marking for irrealis (e.g. hypothetical state of affairs)?
Are verbs marked in a specific mood in counterfactual conditional clauses?
Is there morphological marking on the verb dedicated to the expression of deontic necessity?
Is there morphological marking on the verb dedicated to the expression of epistemic possibility?
Comment: The so-called potential mood is somewhat different from its namesake in Finnish, but sometimes fits into this category.

Name: Is there morphological marking on the verb dedicated to the expression of deontic possibility?
Is there morphological marking on the verb used to express indirect commands/wishes etc. directed to the 3Sg?
Is there morphological marking on the verb used to express indirect commands/wishes etc. directed to the 1Sg?
Is it common to use the imperative/jussive in complement clauses introduced by predicates expressing wish/desire/will?
Is there morphological marking on the verb dedicated to the expression of apprehension?
Is there reflexive conjugation?
Are there syntactically ditransitive verbs?
Comment: However, in some Torne dialects, causative verbs take two objects: Niillas daga-h-ii rávdi niibbi (Niillas make-CAUS-PST.3SG smith.GENACC knife.GENACC). Cf. other dialects: Niillas daga-h-ii rávdái niibbi (Niillas make-CAUS-PST.3SG smith.ILL knife.GENACC) ’Niillas made the smith make him a knife.’

Name: Can non-singular 2nd and 3rd person have the same person/number marking or morphosyntactic treatment?
Can an impersonal (or passive) form be used instead of a finite plural form with an overt subject expression?
Can third person plural verb forms be used for impersonal reference?
Can second person singular verb forms be used in generic meaning?
Comment: Used colloquially, probably increasingly used due to Scandinavian influence.

Name: Are clauses with only infinitive predicates possible?
Comment: The infinitive can be used in imperative sentences.

Name: Can verbs in purposive subordinate clauses be in bare infinitive form?
Are there sentences without overt verbal arguments (e.g. weather verbs)?
Is copula needed for predicate nominals in the 3rd person form of the present tense?
Is a copula needed for predicate nominals in the past and/or future tense?
Can locative adverbial phrases act as predicates without a copula?
Can the same coordinating conjunction be used for NPs, VPs, and clauses?
Comment: Coordination can be expressed several ways: 1) Ánná ja Piera 'Ánná and Piera', 2) Ánná(-guovttos) Piera-in (Ánná.GENACC(-DU) Piera-COM) 'Ánná with Piera'

Name: Does existential negation have a separate operator?
Can standard negation be asymmetric in the present tense?
Can non-finite dependent clauses use the standard negation construction?
Is there a special negator that combines with non-finite forms?
Comment: The purposive infinitive (cf. UT043) can be negated with the element ama- followed by a possessive suffix.

Name: Are there special negative non-finite forms?
Is there an impersonal passive construction?
Are there nonfinite forms specialized on the relativization of particular core participants, e.g. subjects (S/A), direct objects (P), absolutive participants (S/P)?
Comment: The form čállin is traditionally the so-called agentive participle; nowadays it is  often replaced by čállojuvvon (write.PASS.PST.PTCP) or čállán (write.PST.PTCP).

Name: Are there nonfinite forms that can relativize at least all core participants (S/A/P) and possibly also some noncore participants, e.g. locative adverbials, instruments, etc.?
Are there nonfinite forms that can relativize at least some noncore participants, e.g. locative adverbials or instruments, but cannot relativize all or some of the core participants, e.g. subjects?
Is there a specialized negative participial form, which cannot be analyzed as a specific participial marker + negation marker?
Comment: Somewhat surprisingly, the suffix -keahtes has been ignored by most grammars, but it can be labeled as the negative participle.

Name: Is there a future participle?
Are there participles that can encode their subject by possessive suffixes?
Can subject in at least some participial subordinate clauses be encoded in the same way as in independent clauses?
Are there participles that obligatorily agree with the nouns they modify in case and number (in all contexts)?
Comment: The agentive participle is homonymous with the action nominalization except for three-syllable stems, but even then, the agentive participle is identical with the short variant of the action nominalization used in compounds: čállin 1) write + agentive participle (’written by’)  or 2) action nominalization ’(act of) writing’); jorgalan translate-AG.PTCP >< jorgaleapmi translate-AN, but jorgalan- in, e.g., jorgal-an-bargu translate-AN-work

Name: Are there nonfinite forms that can be used both as participles and action nominalizations?
Are there nonfinite forms that can be used both as participles and agentive nominalizations?
Are there nonfinite forms that can be used both as participles and converbs without any additional morphological material, such as case markers?
Comment: The past participle is not commonly, but nevertheless occasionally used as an anterior converb.

Name: Is OV the neutral order in affirmative imperative clauses?
Is it possible to place an object between the negative marker and the main verb in imperative constructions?
Are there preverbs?
Comment: E.g. ovdan ’forth’ + buktit ’bring’ yields ovdanbuktit ~ ovdan buktit ~ buktit ovdan ’present’

Name: Are there verbal prefixes?
Is there diminutive (hypocoristic) marking on verbs?
Can modifiers of action nominalization in agent and patient roles both be encoded like possessors?
Can the modifier of action nominalization in patient role (e.g. "drinking of coffee") be encoded like the direct object?
Do core adjectives agree with the subject noun in number in the predicative position?
Is it possible to form synthetic superlative?
Can adpositions have person/number marking?
Comment: Marginal, but possible.

Name: Are there separate adpositions to express goal, source, and location (without there being syncretism)?
Is case compounding possible?
Are there case categories only found in pronouns?
Does the numeral modification of a noun have an effect on its case selection?
Is the singular form of the noun also used with numerals bigger than 1?
Is there a genitive case that has an affix?
Comment: The original Uralic genitive singular has been lost, but the genitive-accusative plural is <-id > (-j(t)/; thus the genitive case has an affix. Moreover, inflectional paradigms like Anton : Anton-a SG.GEN : Anton-is SG.LOC suggest that -a is the new singular genitive marker for many words.

Name: Is there a case used to express indirect object/receiver/goal (different from a local case)?
Is there a terminative case?
Is there a separate case to indicate without what/who an action takes place / does not take place?
Comment: The abessive case has degrammaticalized into postposition (and even adverb and preposition), but there are still traces of the abessive as a case marker.

Name: Is there a separate case to mark the motion along or by the referent of the noun (prolative)?
Comment: There is a very much case-like suffix -ráigge that would in principle count as a case suffix to some extent, but is not a full case on a par with other cases.

Name: Is there a locative case that marks goal?
Is there a locative case that marks location?
Is there a locative case that marks source?
Is there case syncretism of goal and location marking?
Is there case syncretism of location and source marking?
Are there two sets of local cases?
Is there a third set of local cases?
Is there a separate case for marking the means by which something is carried out (instrumental) and/or accompaniement (comitative)?
Is there a separate case for marking accompaniment, which is different from the instrumental?
Is there a separate case for marking the result of change (translative) and/or a state of being (essive)?
Is there a separate case for marking the state of being (essive), which is different from the translative?
Is there a separate morphological marker for expressing equative meaning?
Is there an inflectional nominal marker for expressing benefactive or destinative semantics independent from the dative?
Is there in addition to the basic declension a declension different from a possessive declension?
Is it possible to use singular with paired body parts/clothing/accessories that accompany them?
Can the marking of the possessor in the attributive construction vary?
Can the possessor in the attributive construction be encoded with the nominative?
Is non-singular possession marked in the possessive declension?
Comment: However, in most spoken varieties possessive forms are very marginal and even quite foreign to many speakers.

Name: Can 2Sg possessive suffix be used to mark definiteness?
Can 3Sg possessive suffix be used to mark definiteness?
Is there human vs. non-human distinction distinction in independent interrogative pronouns?
When used as a relative pronoun, is it common to use 'who' for animates other than humans?
When used as a relative pronoun, is it common to use 'who' for inanimates?
Can a demonstrative stem be used in the function of a pronoun with 3rd person singular human referent?
Are there possessive suffixes whose position in relation to case/number suffixes can vary?
Comment: The dominant  order is cx+px, but the relatively recent comitative plural is an exception.

Name: Is the order of number and case suffixes fixed across the paradigm the same?
Comment: Plural case forms are mostly distinguished from the singular ones by the use of a different set of case suffixes, even though historically these plural suffixes are bimorphemic and contain a plural marker *-j-. From a synchronic perspective, the question about the order of number and case suffixes is irrelevant, though the number and case markers cannot be distinguished.

Name: Are there different words for mother’s brother and father’s brother?
Are there different words for younger and older relative for other relations than siblings?
Is there animacy distinction for both concepts 'new/young' and 'old'?
Comment: There is distinction only for 'young': nuorra – boaris 'young – old' (animate), ođđa – boaris 'new – old' (inanimate). In addition, vuoras ’elderly’ may refer to older persons, but is mostly a noun.

Name: Is there distinction for both 'warm' and 'cold' based on whether referring to weather or to temperature of objects?
Is there contrastive length of consonants?
Comment: Both lexical and grammatical contrast although lexical contrast is not as common as grammatical.

Name: Is there contrastive length of vowels?
Comment: The contrastive length of vowels is present in the Western Inland dialects and in the Eastern Inland dialects. They differ from each other a lot in terms of phonetic realization of single vowels and diphthongs. Length is not straight-forwardly marked in standard orthography.

Name: Is there contrast between short and long unstressed vowels?
Comment: Mostly for unstressed a : aa, marginally for other vowels.

Name: Is there contrast in duration of geminate consonants?
Comment: This difference is not marked in standard orthography. In dictionaries and grammars, the apostrophe is often used to mark Q3.

Name: Are there more than two phonological quantities?
Comment: There are three phonological quantities in the intervocalic consonant but the consonantal quantity also affects the surrounding segments, especially V1.

Name: Are there extralong syllables?
Is the main foot structure trochaic?
Comment: Primary word stress is always on the first syllable.

Name: Is there lexically distinctive word stress?
Is there morphologically conditioned stress?
Comment: A stressed syllable is followed by one or two unstressed syllables. If a word has four or more syllables, every other syllable is stressed.

Name: Is there fixed primary stress?
Comment: Primary word stress is always on the first syllable.

Name: Is there stress in heavy syllables?
Is there non-initial primary stress?
Is there palatal vowel harmony?
Is there velar vowel harmony?
Is there labial vowel harmony?
Are there rising diphthongs?
Are there lowering diphthongs?
Is there qualitative contrast between subsets of short and long vowels?
Are there full vs. reduced vowels as contrastive subsets?
Is there front high rounded vowel ü [y]?
Comment: Not in autochthonous vocabulary, but in various loanwords as well as in diphthongs in certain dialects.

Name: Is there front midhigh rounded vowel ö [ø]?
Comment: Not in autochthonous vocabulary, but in various loanwords as well as in diphthongs in certain dialects.

Name: Is there back high unrounded vowel ï [ɯ]?
Is there back midhigh unrounded vowel ë [ɤ]?
Is there back low round vowel [ɒ]?
Comment: [ɒ] is found in dialects spoken in Utsjoki, Karasjok, Tana etc., perhaps about 30–40 % of the speakers of the language.

Name: Is there contrast between low and mid front vowels (ä [æ] vs. e [e])?
Comment: In the easternmost dialects.

Name: Are there word-initial consonant clusters?
Comment: In the easternmost dialects. However, all speakers in Norway and Sweden (western dialects) have an ever-increasing number of Scandinavian loan words with word-initial consonant clusters. For example, the city of Tromsø is officially Romsa, but popularly Tromsa [tromsa], clearly the Saami name for [trumsø].

Name: Are there word-internal consonant clusters in syllable onset?
Are there consonant clusters in syllable coda?
Are there clusters of three or more consonants in a word between vowels?
Are there word-final clusters of three or more consonants?
Are there palatalized dentals?
Comment: In the absence of phonetic studies, it may be a matter of taste whether the ”palatal” consonants include /nʲ/ or /ɲ/.

Name: Are there palatalized labials and velars?
Is there palatal stop [c]?
Comment: There is /tʲ/ instead of /c/.

Name: Is there palatal nasal [ɲ]?
Comment: See UT146.

Name: Is there palatal lateral [ʎ]?
Comment: There is /lʲ/ instead of /ʎ/.

Name: Is there phonemic velar nasal [ŋ]?
Comment: Present in the eastern dialects.

Name: Is there dental affricate [t͡s]?
Is there non-alveolar affricate (e.g. [t͡ʃ], [͡cɕ])?
Comment: In the absence of phonetic studies, it may be a matter of taste whether the non-dental consonants include /t͡ʃ/ and /ʃ/ or /t͡ɕ/ and /ɕ/.

Name: Is there a phonological contrast between [s] and postalveolar sibilant [ʃ]?
Comment: In the absence of phonetic studies, it may be a matter of taste whether the non-dental consonants include /t͡ʃ/ and /ʃ/ or /t͡ɕ/ and /ɕ/.

Name: Are there voiced plosives [b, g, d]?
Is there glottal stop [ˀ]?
Is there phonological contrast between plain and labial velar consonants (e.g. [k] vs. [kʷ])?
Is there a constraint on word-initial r?
Is there laryngeal fricative [h]?
Comment: Pronunciation as in the Eastern dialect.

Name: Is there voiced velar fricative [ɣ]?
Comment: The last remnants of /ɣ/ in the eastern dialects seem to have disappeared by the 21th century.

Name: Is there voiceless velar fricative [x]?
Is there voiced dental fricative [ð]?
Is there phonemic labio-velar approximant [w]?
Is there voiceless labiodental fricative [f]?
Is there radical qualitative consonant gradation?
Is there quantitative consonant gradation?
